Author: nopassrecover
Content: I agree that giving the power of extradition to an employer or investor is ultimately going to undermine the benefits that the business relationship brought in the first place. However, how do you define 'excellent'? A uni degree isn't indicative of excellent. It's not even a required component of 'excellent'.

Author: elblanco
Content: Well, different people are having different takes on the semantics I guess. How about a quota though? Nobody likes an overly negative person at a party. IRL, we can't enforce good behavior that way, but here we can through the power of software.

Author: cstross
Content:
Yes, this.

Cringely opined some years ago that tech companies evolve through three categories (or stages of development): technology driven, sales driven, and marketing driven.

There's an assumption in this ontology: that growth and evolution of a tech company is predicated on new technology.

The new (post-1997, Jobs II) Apple breaks this rule. Apple is design driven, at a level that makes more sense to folks with a Fine Art degree than a CS background. (The reason for their success? Lots of folks with an aesthetic background like this stuff and will pay extra for it.) They're seeking a better user experience, vertically integrated at all levels with their web ecosystem.

Gruber -- who's been tracking apple for something like 20 years -- gets this. J. Random Gizmo columnist doesn't.

Author: glymor
Content:
[Apple] realized that keeping WebKit closed and exclusively pumping money into it was pointless. So they opened it out...

Webkit started as a fork of KHTML (part of KDE and LGPL licenced) their mishandling of it is a good example of how not to work with open source.

Andriod is another. As Google isn't developing it in public they're carrying the full cost. And their re-creating of userland libraries to avoid the LGPL is pretty much the opposite of your argument (though possibly inherited from before Google bought Android).

Aside from your examples I agree with your point. It's similar to one Doctorow makes in Makers that everything turns into a commodity after a few years and it doesn't make you money anymore. However it can still act as a barrier of entry so examples like Chadaustin's can still make sense if maintenance costs don't dominate.

Author: axod
Content:
You can use iptables to rate limit connections:

  -N SSH_RECENT
  -A INPUT -m state --state NEW -p tcp --dport 22 -j SSH_RECENT
  -A SSH_RECENT -m recent --set --name SSH
  -A SSH_RECENT -m recent --update --seconds 60 --hitcount 3 --name SSH -j DROP
